name: Playtex

explanation: Playtex is owned by Hanesbrands Incorporated. Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain however it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It received a good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.  This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.  Playtex is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

It measures and reports on water usage and wastewater management and publicly reports on targets.  Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain however it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It received a good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.  This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.  Just My Size is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

name: Mountain Hardwear
description: Mountain Hardware has committed to reduce carbon emissions but does not assure payment of a living wage
explanation: Mountain Hardware is owned by the Columbia Sportswear Company. Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. Around 60% of its textiles are sourced from Bluesign certified mills. The majority of its range uses non eco-friendly materials but it is starting to use more recycled polyester. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste in its manufacturing and operations parts of its supply chain. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions, but only for its North American operations which excludes most of its manufacturing. It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals but it complies with a Restricted Substances List. 95% of its leather is sourced from Leather Working Group accredited tanneries, but it does not state their level of certification. It has no water reduction initiatives or policies. It measures and reports on water usage and wastewater management, but only for facilities which it owns. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition. Its labor rating is 'it's a start'. It has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct based on the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct Workplace Code of Conduct. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse but attempts to address those risks through affiliation with the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct and Uzbek Cotton Pledge. It mentions paying a living wage and supplies an adequate definition, however it does not assure its payment. It traces suppliers in its manufacturing and material inputs parts of its supply chain, and it has publicly shared a list of suppliers, although it is unclear whether this is complete or not. It audits some of its supply chain once a year by third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing and all of its audits are unannounced. Its animal rating is 'good'. It uses down feather, but 100% of this is accredited by the Responsible Down Standard and it uses wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, shearling, angora, or exotic animal hair or skin. However it uses leather without specifying its sources. Mountain Hardwear is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Its environmental rating is 'not good enough', it is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition and the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP).It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear target. It has adopted the American Apparel and Footwear Association’s Restricted Substance List, However it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Supplier Code of Conduct based off the ILO Conventions, Fair labor Standards Act and UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. It is part of the Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety and Business for Social Responsibility (BSR) but it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It traces suppliers in part of its supply chain and some of its supply chain is independently audited. However tere is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down feather or exotic animal skin or hair. Trouvé is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on informational from our own research.

types: activewear, tops, denim, dresses, knitwear, swimwear, bags
name: prAna
description: prAna uses eco-friendly materials but has not set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target.
explanation: prAna is owned by Columbia Sportswear. Its environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.  Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.  Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It does not use fur, angora, exotic animal skin or exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It uses leather and wool. prAna is rated 'It's a start' overall.

name: ODLO
description: ODLO has good policies to audit suppliers in its supply chain but is not taking adequate steps to minimise textile waste.
explanation: ODLO is owned by Monte Rosa Sport.  Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it has set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.  Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It is a member of the Fair Wear Foundation. It has some worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It has a project to improve wages in some of its supply chain. It audits its suppliers regularly.  Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It does not use fur, angora, exotic animal skin or hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses leather and down. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.  ODLO is rated 'It's a start' overall.

name: Hurley
description: Hurley has set some ambitious environmental goals but there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
explanation: Hurley International is owned by Nike Inc. Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a low proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic and recycled cotton and recycled polyester. It minimises off-cuts in parts of its manufacturing process and has a strategy in place to reduce waste in a large portion of its supply chain. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its emissions by >50% by the year 2025. It has not made a commitment to eliminating hazardous chemicals from its supply chain but it complies with a Restricted Substances List guided by the Zero Discharge of Hazardous Chemicals Group (ZDHC). It reports on its water usage and wastewater management and implements water reduction initiatives. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition; however its chemicals policy has attracted criticism from Greenpeace Detox Catwalk.  Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It may publicly list some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.  This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.  Hurley International is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

name: Big W
description: Big W does not have adequate policies on greenhouse gas emissions and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
explanation: Big W is owned by Woolworths Ltd. Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials and it does not offer any warranties or repair programs on its products but it is taking steps to minimise the use of packaging. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions and has set an absolute greenhouse gas target. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. It has water reduction initiatives but has not set any specific reduction targets.  Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It may publicly list some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period and has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.  Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses wool and leather without specifying its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.  Big W is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

name: Sonoma
description: Sonoma is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals or trace suppliers in its supply chain
explanation: Sonoma is owned by Kohl’s Corporation. Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste across its supply chain. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions, but it has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It covers most workers’ rights principles in its Code of Conduct. It pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not in definition of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear to what extent. It does not use down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair. In 2014, some of its faux fur products were found to be made of real fur. Sonoma is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

It received a good score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. However it traces only one stage of its supply chain, it likely does not publicly list its suppliers and it does not guarantee that subcontracting does not occur in any of its supply chain. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period and it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.  This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.  La Senza is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

explanation: Mata Traders's rating applies to Mata Traders only and does not cover other brands stocked by it. Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It reduces its climate impact by producing its products by hand. It uses low impact dyes in some of its products. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. Its labour rating is 'great'. It is a member of the WFTO Guarantee System. It has a mission to improve working conditions for workers in India and Nepal. It ensures payment of a living wage to all of its final stage of production. It traces most of its supply chain.  Its animal rating is 'good'. There is no evidence that it uses animal products but does not mention being vegan.  Mata Traders is rated 'Good' overall.

name: HoMie
description: HoMie is a streetwear clothing social enterprise that donates 100% of its profits to support people experiencing homelessness or hardship.
explanation: HoMie's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including upcycled materials. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.  Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Most of its factories are audited and reported through Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit - SMETA Best Practice Guidance. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.  Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.  HoMie is rated 'Good' overall.

name: Oliberté
description: A shoe and bag brand that owns and operates the world's first Fair Trade Certified factory, based in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
explanation: Olibertés environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It has its own policy to reduce chromium from its leather tanning processes. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.   Its labour rating is 'great'. Its products are Fair Trade USA certified. It sources from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse but it ensures a payment of a living wage to all of its final stage of production. It traces most of its supply. It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.   Its animal rating is 'it's a start' It does not use wool, fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses leather.   Oliberté is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

name: Mercado Global
description: Mercado Global creates unique hand-woven bags and homewares that empower indigenous women to overcome poverty & become agents of change in their communities
explanation: Mercado Global's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not provide enough information on its material use and sourcing. However it is in the process of eliminating hazardous chemicals and it limits its carbon emissions by handcrafting its products using traditional and artisanal Mayan methods. It uses leather from TATA International which recycles the chemical chromium from the leather tanning process.  Its labour rating is 'great'. It is a social enterprise that exists to provide employment for women and indigenous artisans in rural Guatemalan communities. It has programs in place to give its artisans access to business training and community-based education programs as well as microloans for technology such as sewing machines and floor looms. It addresses workers' rights and mentions payment of a living wage. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but attempts to address those risks by tracing suppliers in all of its supply chain. It publishes a complete list of suppliers and audits more than once a year by third party or internal auditors.  Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather sourced from TATA international, under high environmental standards however there is no mention of animal treatment. It uses wool without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. Mercado Global is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

name: C&A
description: C&A uses eco-friendly materials but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
explanation: C&A's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It implements some water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2020 but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) including the final, second and first stages of production. It received a score of 61-70% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production, some information about the second and first stages of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain however there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of Covid-19. Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production. C&A is rated 'It's a start' overall.

name: Wonderbra
description: Wonderbra traces most of its supply chain but does not use eco-friendly materials
explanation: Wonderbra is owned by Hanesbrands Incorporated. Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it recycles some off-cuts created during the manufacturing process. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but does not do so for its entire supply chain and it does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions. It has made a public commitment to reduce its carbon emissions by 40% by the year 2020 and it has taken meaningful action on meeting its carbon reduction target. It complies with a Restricted Substances List however it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals from its supply chain. It measures and reports on water usage and wastewater management and publicly reports on targets.  Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain however it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It received a good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.  This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.  Wonderbra is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

name: Timberland
description: Timberland has made a public commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
explanation: Timberland is owned by VF Corporation. Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It uses recycled packaging. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers. Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur, down or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production . Timberland is rated 'It's a start' overall.

name: WE-AR
description: WE-AR clothing is designed for existential living, specialising in men and women's yoga and casual wear
explanation: WE-AR's environmental rating is ‘good’. It uses some organic cotton, linen and lyocell but also uses conventional cotton, polyester, acrylic, suede and wool. However, it does set a yearly target to increase the amount of environmentally friendly materials that it uses, which is encouraging. It uses azo-free dyes and tries to use as many plant based dyes as possible. It uses waste reduction methods in its production and upcycles its fabric offcuts to make other products. It also provides a repair scheme if an item is faulty. Finally it has a policy which includes reducing energy and water consumption in its operations Its labour rating is ‘good’. It produces all of its clothing in Bali, Indonesia, an extreme-risk country for labour rights. However, all items are made in home-workshops and small factories and it has a clear and detailed code of conduct which includes safe and fair working conditions and a living wage policy. WE-AR regularly checks with the workers to see if they are content with their wages and conditions. It is also creating an ethical manufacturing charter for Bali in conjunction with other stakeholders. For its workers based in NZ, it is an accredited living wage employer.  It’s animal rating is ‘it's a start’. It does not use fur or angora, but does use leather without specifying its sources. It also uses wool which comes from non-mulesed sources.  WE-AR is a certified B Corporation and donates $1 of every purchase towards social projects such as an HIV/AIDS outreach program in Bali. WE-AR is rated ‘Good’ based on our own research.

name: Slowear
description: Slowear does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies.
explanation: Slowear's environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.  Its labour rating is 'very poor'. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It has a Code of Conduct that does not include any of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms labour standards. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.  Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and wool. It does not use fur, down, angora, or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production. Slowear is rated 'We avoid' overall.

name: Outland Denim
description: Outland Denim crafts premium denim jeans and offers sustainable employment and training opportunities to women who have experienced exploitation.
explanation: Outland Denim's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.  Its labour rating is 'great'. It is a social enterprise that assists in creating employment opportunities for women who have been trafficked in Cambodia. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather.  Outland Denim is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.

name: Triarchy
description: Triarchy is a brand that creates modern denim pieces using tencel and cotton blends.
explanation: Triarchy's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled cotton. It uses a closed-loop system to reduce water use. It manages the treatment and discharge of wastewater in its supply chain. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals used in production.  Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It sources its final stage of production from countries with high risk of labour abuse. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces all of its supply chain.  Its animal rating is 'great'. It is listed by PETA as vegan.  Triarchy is rated 'Great' overall.

It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but implementation is uncertain. Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.  Monki is rated 'It's a start' overall.

name: Le Pirol
description: Le Pirol is a Nordic knitwear brand tailored for a modern, sustainable lifestyle.
explanation: Le Pirol's environment rating is 'great'. It is fully certified by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS). It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint.Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.  Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Denmark, a low risk country for labour abuse. It traces most of its supply chain including all of final stage of production. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits most of its supply chain.  Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep.  Le Pirol is rated 'Great' overall.

name: Ahnu
description: Ahnu is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
explanation: Ahnu is owned by Deckers Outdoor Corporation (Deckers Brands) Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions, and has made a public commitment to reduce its Scope 3 emissions by 4 % during 2017. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. However it uses a REACH compliant Restricted Substances List, and 98% of its leather is sourced from Leather Working Group certified tanneries. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management for the majority of its supply chain. Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers' rights principles in its Code of Conduct but it is unclear if it applies to all of its supply chain. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces its manufacturing suppliers and it has publicly shared a complete list of its factories with addresses. It conducts audits once a year using third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing, and uses unannounced audits, however it does not audit all of its supply chain. Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use wool, down and feathers, or shearling in its products, and it has policies prohibiting the use of fur, angora, and exotic animal skin. However it uses leather without stating its sources. Ahnu is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

name: Sol Y Oro
description: Sol Y Oro traces most of its supply chain but does not use eco-friendly materials
explanation: Sol Y Oro is owned by Hanesbrands Incorporated. Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it recycles some off-cuts created during the manufacturing process. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but does not do so for its entire supply chain and it does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions. It has made a public commitment to reduce its carbon emissions by 40% by the year 2020 and it has taken meaningful action on meeting its carbon reduction target. It complies with a Restricted Substances List however it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals from its supply chain. It measures and reports on water usage and wastewater management and publicly reports on targets.  Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain however it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It received a good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.  This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.  Sol Y Oro is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.  . Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan. explanation: Veja's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. Its tanneries are audited by the Leather Working Group. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.  Its labour rating is 'great'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It monitors health and safety issues by visiting all of its final stage of production suppliers. It ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces all of its supply chain.  Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather.  Veja is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

name: Clarks
description: Clarks does not have strong environmental policies and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
explanation: Clarks is owned by C&J Clark International Ltd. Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials or have any strategies in place to reduce waste. It is taking steps to use 100% post-consumer waste materials in its packaging. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions, but has not set a target for direct or indirect emissions reduction. It has taken some steps to offset its emissions in the retail and operations section of its supply chain. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain, but it complies with a Restricted Substances List. Over 75% of its leather is sourced from at least bronze-certified Leather Working Group tanneries. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management. Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Global Social Compliance Program (GSCP). It has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risks of labour abuse, and it pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not in definition of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its manufacturing and inputs production sections of its supply chain but not in its first stage of production. It has listed the countries of its suppliers but it does not share a complete list. It audits once a year by third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing, but it does not use unannounced audits. Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool from unspecified sources. It does not use down, angora, shearling, fur, or exotic animal hair or skin. Clarks is rated 'Not Good Enough', based on information from our own research.

name: Henri Bendel
description: Henri Bendel does not use eco-friendly materials or ensure payment of a living wage across its supply chain
explanation: Henri Bendel is owned by L Brands. Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions, but not for its entire supply chain and it does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting. It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It has set a deadline for the elimination of hazardous chemicals by 2020 and it complies with a Restricted Substances List. It also has water reduction initiatives but has not set a specific reduction target. It participates in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP).  Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received a good score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. However it traces only one stage of its supply chain, it likely does not publicly list its suppliers and it does not guarantee that subcontracting does not occur in any of its supply chain. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period and it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.  Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather without stating its sources. It does not use wool, down, fur, angora, exotic animal skin or hair.  Henri Bendel is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

description: Louis Vuitton uses fur, angora and exotic animal products.
explanation: Louis Vuitton is owned by LVMH. Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals.  Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in medium risk countries for labour abuse. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19. Its animal rating is 'very poor'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses fur, down, leather, wool, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production. Louis Vuitton is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

name: nat & nin
description: Nat & Nin offers leather bags and accessories for women
explanation: nat & nin's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It produces long lasting products. There is no evidence of it reducing its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. There is no evidence it avoids hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. There is no evidence that it implements water reduction initiatives.   Its labour rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its labour practices.   Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin and exotic animal hair.   nat & nin is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

name: Michael Kors
description: Michael Kors uses angora and exotic animal skin.
explanation: Michael Kors is owned by Capri Holdings.  Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has a policy to prevent deforestation in the supply chain. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2025 but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.  Its labour rating is 'very poor'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes zero or very limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.  Its animal rating is 'very poor'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather, wool, angora, down, exotic animal skin and exotic animal hair. It does use fur. There is no evidence it traces animal products to the first stage of production. Michael Kors is rated 'We avoid' overall.
